docs.abstract: The brain-tingling feeling was a hard-to-describe psychological oddity. Until, suddenly, it was a YouTube phenomenon.
docs.snippet: The brain-tingling feeling was a hard-to-describe psychological oddity. Until, suddenly, it was a YouTube phenomenon.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Jennifer Allen watched videos of space, she sometimes felt this peculiar sensation: a tingling that spread through her scalp as the camera pulled back to show the marble of the earth. It came in a wave, like a warm effervescence, making its way down the length of her spine and leaving behind a sense of gratitude and wholeness. Allen loved this feeling, but she didn’t know what caused it. It was totally distinct from anything she’d experienced before. Every two years or so she’d take to Google. She tried searching things like “tingling head and spine” or “brain orgasm.” For nine years, the search didn’t turn up anything.

docs.abstract: Humans will always find a way to overcomplicate even the simplest things.
docs.snippet: Humans will always find a way to overcomplicate even the simplest things.
docs.lead_paragraph: — From “The New Rules of Coffee” (Ten Speed Press 2018, Page 109), by Jordan Michelman and Zachary Carlsen, founders of a coffee-focused media network called Sprudge.

headline.main: Gary Keith and Ron, the Magi of Mets Nation

docs.abstract: Do cheese and crackers count? What about if you add pickles?
docs.snippet: Do cheese and crackers count? What about if you add pickles?
docs.lead_paragraph: Brad writes: My wife, Kristena, says her favorite meal is meat, cheese and pickles on a cracker. I believe that is a snack, not a meal. When asked if she would like a special birthday dinner consisting of only that, she said yes! She even claims that this snack becomes a sandwich if another cracker is placed on top. Please bring justice before my wife’s delusions get worse.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on What Constitutes a Meal
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: A book on Victorian marriage doubles as a case for the transformative power of gossip.
docs.snippet: A book on Victorian marriage doubles as a case for the transformative power of gossip.
docs.lead_paragraph: This summer I asked almost everyone I met to tell me the story of his or her life. (We were in the right season for gossip — confidences rise and fall with the humidity index.) I was not so concerned with honesty. “True story” is already something of an oxymoron. Instead I wanted the character arcs people wrote for themselves, tales that ended with the moment they sat down on a chair in front of me. The good gossips among them knew to deflect — “Tell me the story of your life” — but no matter who went first, we always started, or claimed to start, at the beginning.

headline.main: Letter of Recommendation: Phyllis Rose’s ‘Parallel Lives’

docs.abstract: Call, email, write, send pictures. Try to visit — but don’t harp when you do.
docs.snippet: Call, email, write, send pictures. Try to visit — but don’t harp when you do.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Do everything you can to stay in touch,” says Janja Lalich, a sociology professor and consultant who studies cults and coercive influence and control. If you’re trying to persuade someone to leave a cult, supply reminders of the world beyond it by calling, emailing, writing letters, sending photographs and maybe even visiting, although Lalich warns that anyone can get lured into a cult. You should visit “only if you feel strong enough to resist,” she says.

headline.main: How to Get Someone Out of a Cult
headline.print_headline: How to Get Someone Out of a Cult

docs.lead_paragraph: Threaded through Laura Swearingen-Steadwell’s collection “All Blue So Late” is a clutch of poems bearing the same title and number of lines: Fourteen. It’s both a nod to the sonnet and to the age of her female protagonist, a biracial “nerd-jock” struggling to fit in as she navigates the bewildering flux of adolescence. This poem deftly volleys between acceptance on the soccer field, where “brown is/an international color,” and anger provoked by racial and sexual slurs encountered in the everyday adult world. Selected by Rita Dove

docs.abstract: Specialist Jessica Sarandrea’s death dimmed a light on her family, who left Miami to live in a place where they weren’t surrounded by reminders of the daughter they lost.
